Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Events in Language and Cognition 2016

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Language and communication are fundamental to being human. Alone of all animals, humans can tell one another their thoughts and pass along proposals, instructions, warnings, and other ideas. Despite great scientific and technological advances in understanding formal properties of language such as grammar, relatively little is known about how language conveys thought. One major reason is that in order to explain how language conveys thought, we need to understand the structure of thought itself. The structure of thought is not well understood, particularly when it comes to thoughts about events (building a house, eating dinner, etc.). As a result, our understanding of how language conveys events is particularly poor. Without this missing piece, our understanding of human nature is incomplete and our language technology is limited. One difficulty in accounting for how humans use language to describe and discuss events is that--in addition to the fact that events are highly abstract and thus difficult to study--work on event representations is scattered across different scientific fields with different theoretical underpinnings, methods, and terminologies. This workshop has been organized to bridge these differences by bringing together leading researchers to share recent advances, assess the state of the research, build ties between research fields, and plot a way forward.

The one-day workshop will consist of two invited presentations, seven juried talks, a poster session with approximately 20 posters, and a closing discussion. The poster session will help ensure ample opportunity for student presentations and involvement. In keeping with the interdisciplinary focus of the meeting, one invited speaker is a linguist and the other is a psychologist who specializes in language acquisition, and the closing discussion will be led by two researchers who study events from a non-linguistic perspective. Juried talks and posters will be chosen with an eye towards diversity in seniority, demographics, research tradition, and phenomenon of interest. The workshop is co-located with the premier American psycholinguistics conference (the CUNY Human Sentence Processing conference), since many attendees at that conference have research expertise relating to both language and thought.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded a one-day focused workshop on a timely and important question in the study of language and cognition: How do languages allow us to communication information about events to one another? This is not just a question about language, but about psychology, since it makes direct contact with theories of how humans think about and understand events. 

This workshop brought together nearly 50 psycholinguists to discuss the latest results, provide feedback on one another's work, and plot a way forward. The workshop included keynotes by two preeminent researchers in the field (Jesse Snedeker and Elsi Kaiser), plus 7 research talks and 18 posters chosen through a competitive review process. Research covered a variety of phenomena as well as different languages and populations. The workshop concluded with a lively panel discussion, including the two keynote speakers, two invited guests (Elliot Saltzmann, an expert on action planning, and Jeremy Skipper, an expert in event cognition), and the three organizers (Joshua Hartshorne, Melissa Kline, and Eva Wittenberg).

Intellectual merit: Event cognition has been studied independently in a number of different disciplines and subfields. A major goal for this workshop was to bring some of these different lines of work together in order to provide opportunities for synthesis and cross-pollination. Oral presentations included developmental research, adult psycholinguistics, cognitive neuroscience, assessments of linguistic theories, and computational modeling. The panelists synthesized the day’s presentations and debated future directions. There was considerable enthusiasm from the attendees for repeating the event in the future, suggesting that the workshop succeeded in facilitating the creation of a community.

Broader impacts: As already noted, this workshop served to cross-pollinate different research programs and help develop a more unified research community around events and language. This dialog continued at the 2016 meeting of the Cognitive Science Society, where “event cognition” was independently chosen as the theme (providing further evidence of the timeliness of the workshop). A follow-up workshop is in the planning stages. The workshop was also successful in providing exposure for younger researchers, with oral presentations and panel participation by junior faculty (Hartshorne), post-docs (Wittenberg, Kline, Noortje Venhuizen, Johannes Gerwien), and a graduate student (Laurel Perkins). In addition, a number of younger researchers presented posters.
